meta.title: BALI MODERN: The Art of Tropical Living
meta.author: Gianni Francione (text) & Luca Invernizzi Tettoni (photography)

parts.title: The New Bali Style: A Blend of Tradition and Modernity
parts.body: The New Bali Style is about combining local and international influences in architecture. Tracing its roots to Bali's unique culture and landscape, this style blends Western comfort with Balinese tradition. It's not just design—it's a reflection of the island's spiritual heritage, harmonizing human and environmental elements. Emerging from Hindu-Buddhist and animist traditions, Bali's architecture thrives on the balance of microcosm and macrocosm. As tourism grew, Bali evolved, blending old with new—a charming mix of traditional elements and modern living.

parts.title: Bali Architecture: A Fusion of Worlds
parts.body: The article introduces Bali's evolving architectural landscape influenced by contemporary and traditional elements. Modern materials like ceramics, stone, and glass are replacing the classic Balinese woods and bamboos, yet fusion designs balance both Western and local aesthetics. One standout example is a villa in Ubud designed by two Australian artists showcasing minimalist geometric volumes and vibrant interiors crafted by the owners with artistic ceramic tiles. Their work encapsulates a colorful blend of objects that radiate the region's tropical joie de vivre.

parts.title: The Conical House in Canggu
parts.body: The Conical House is a villa located on a hilltop in Canggu, boasting amazing ricefield views. Designed by a French architect, it features a linear form with conical elements based on West Timor architecture, specifically the lopo. The modern design integrates these traditional round volumes in a residential setting, creating a harmonious blend between vernacular forms and a contemporary context. A covered walkway flanked by a lotus pond and colorful frangipani and bougainvillea welcomes guests into the villa's interior room. The architecture uses wood, alang-alang, and local stones like ivory marble and sandstone, providing an impressive yet intimate atmosphere with well-planned geometries and proportions. The villa's pool features a mosaic tile layout that creates a crystal blue water effect, accentuated by natural sand-colored stone and lush gardens, offering an inviting, cool, and clean ambiance. A wooden foot-bridge across a water garden leads to the villa entrance, enhancing its charm and tranquility.

parts.title: Shingle Wings: A Grand Design Amidst Nature
parts.body:
Shingle Wings: A Tropical Butterfly

The house in the vibrant Seminyak area features a unique butterfly-wing roof designed by GM Architects in 1997. These wings frame a central area with bedrooms and kitchen, the walls clad in ivory limestone. Below each wing, the living and dining areas provide a serene view of the lush surrounding garden, blending indoor and outdoor spaces seamlessly. The entrances open up with a triangular glass feature above, offering a rare sky-view from inside, enhancing the harmonious blend of architecture and nature. The villa sits gracefully amidst tall palms and a clear water feature, creating a bright, airy ambiance. Notably, the open-to-the-garden bathroom shadows under an ancient tree, promoting a feeling of being one with nature. The use of different materials, like Bengkerai wood for the roof and flooring, contrasts with outdoor white pebbles, adding a natural, yet modern touch to the architectural design.

parts.title: Unique Balinese Designs Highlighted by Luxury and Mystical Elements
parts.body: Octagonal Opulence In this unique villa, rich in symbolism and strange shapes, extensive use of terrazzo blends with materials like bleached tropical wood, mother-of-pearl inlay, and stained glass for a creative effect. Located 100 meters from the beach in the Petitenggett area, this house designed by a fashion designer, incorporates feng-shui principles and other mystical elements. The entrance has a traditional Balinese portal as an aling aling to protect against bad spirits. The villa's design features two octagonal structures, with high-quality terrazzo used throughout indoors for floors, walls, and furnishings. Challenging Nature Nestled in the Sayan Ridge valley, the Four Seasons Resort Bali at Sayan combines modern architecture with the tropical environment. Designed by John Heah and Co, it features twenty-eight private villas that blend with their surroundings using natural materials like ivory-tone cladding. The main structure includes a lobby, restaurant, and 18 suites accessible by a dramatic footbridge over 65 feet high, leading to a large lotus pond. A rich interplay of architecture is seen throughout the property, characterized by a mixture of galleries, bridges, and walkways.

parts.title: The Majestic Pool and Terrace Walkway
parts.body: ## The Majestic Pool and Terrace Walkway The majestic pool is enclosed by a composition of stone walls, creating a natural, earthy vibe contrasted with a charming alang-alang grass roof. The view from the terrace walkway above the pool offers a spectacular landscape to admire. The space is adorned with primitive artifacts, adding an artistic touch to the surroundings. Natural shadows accentuate the clean, columned walkway. This setting perfectly complements the tropical living theme by harmonizing with the indigenous nature while achieving an atmosphere of relaxation and elegance.

parts.title: Bali’s Beautiful Landscapes
parts.body:
Bali’s Beautiful Landscapes

The bale in Bali traditionally represents simplicity and beauty. Originally used in villages for meetings and ceremonies, bales decided to evolve over time. Nowadays, bales adorn luxurious resorts, offering an array of functionalities from relaxing loungers to unique dining pavilions. Modern elements like stone and metal now complement this classic Balinese architecture, giving them a modern twist while still encapsulating the essence of Balinese culture.

Modern Aesthetics

Designers are incorporating innovative aesthetics; imagine thatched roofs and awnings over modern materials like ivory stone and wicker. These bales are strategically positioned by pools or lily ponds, creating serene oases for guests to savor the tranquility of lush natural beauty. A standout feature is the use of traditional granary designs fused with contemporary concepts, inducing an atmosphere of tropical luxury.

parts.title: Tropical Water Features & Architectural Harmony
parts.body:
Tropical Water Features & Architectural Harmony

Balinese cultures hold water as a vital element of life. This section explores how contemporary and traditional architecture integrates water to create serenity and aesthetic appeal. In Estate Begawan, natural springs play an integral part by filling pools and even bathroom facilities, creating a continuous chain of refreshment across the compound. Such springs are sacred, used in Hindu rituals, providing both nourishment and inspiring design. The Umabona villa offers a breathtaking view from its master bedroom, where a two-tiered pool connects with the surrounding jungle and offers spectacular sunsets. Another innovative example is the Lotus Pond, which serves as the rooftop of the main complex, offering both a playful feature and a meditative charm. Through these architectural styles, water becomes an element of beauty, functionality, and spiritual significance.
